software.leonov.progress

Class ProgressMonitor

  • java.lang.Object
    • software.leonov.progress.ProgressMonitor

  • public final class ProgressMonitor
extends Object
    A ProgressMonitor can be used to track the progress of a long running operation.

    Basic usage: 

    
 final ProgressMonitor progress = ProgressMonitor.create().addProgressListener(event -> ...);

 while (...) {
     ...
     progress.increment();
 }

 progress.completed();

    Step size and ProgressEvents:

    When this class is instantiated, the minimum and maximum step size will be set to the DEFAULT_MIN_STEP_SIZE and DEFAULT_MAX_STEP_SIZE respectively. As the progress count is updated, ProgressEvents are published commensurate with the step size, which will gradually increases from the specified minimum to the maximum size. No duplicate events will be published.

    The step size can be set to a constant value by calling setStepSize(long). A different maximum and minimum range can be defined by calling setDynamicStepSize(long, long).

    Maximum value:

    Specifying the maximum value is not mandatory. However, if specified, it's important to note that the progress count cannot surpass the maximum value. If the initial value proves to be underestimated, it should be adjusted to prevent an IllegalArgumentException when the progress count surpasses it.

    Progress completion:

    In typical scenarios completed() should be called when the operation has concluded. In cases where the operation might raise an exception, it may be appropriate to call completed within the finally clause of a try statement. Calling completed multiple times is explicitly permitted and will have no subsequent effect. Attempts to modify the progress count after calling completed will result in an IllegalStateException until it is reset.

    Thread safety:

    This class is not thread safe. In a concurrent environment access to this class must be synchronized externally. Typically only the increment() or setProgress(long) method are called while the operation is in progress. A simple synchronized block is usually sufficient to ensure thread safety for most use cases: 

    
     ...
     synchronized(...) {
         progress.increment();
     }
     ...
    Author:
    Zhenya Leonov

    • Method Detail

      • addProgressListener

        public ProgressMonitor addProgressListener(ProgressListener listener)
        Adds the specified listener to handle ProgressEvents.
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to add
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance

      • setStepSize

        public ProgressMonitor setStepSize(long stepSize)
        Sets the specified constant step size.
        Parameters:
        stepSize - the specified step size
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance

      • setDynamicStepSize

        public ProgressMonitor setDynamicStepSize(long minStepSize,
                                          long maxStepSize)
        Sets the range for the step size, which dynamically adjusts as the progress count is updated using increment() and setProgress(long). The step size gradually increases from the specified minimum to the maximum size.
        Parameters:
        minStepSize - the minimum step size
        maxStepSize - the maximum step size
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if minStepSize <= 0, maxStepSize <= 0, or maxStepSize < minMaxSize

      • setMaximum

        public ProgressMonitor setMaximum(long maximum)
        Sets the maximum value. This method may be called more than once to reset the maximum value if this ProgressMonitor has not completed.
        Parameters:
        maximum - the maximum value
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this ProgressMonitor has completed
        IllegalArgumentException - if maximum < 1 or maximum < progress

      • getMaximum

        public OptionalLong getMaximum()
        Returns the maximum value.
        Returns:
        the maximum value

      • increment

        public long increment()
        Increments the progress count by 1, publishing a ProgressEvent if necessary.
        Returns:
        the new progress count
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this ProgressMonitor has completed
        IllegalArgumentException - if the new count > maximum

      • setProgress

        public ProgressMonitor setProgress(long count)
        Sets the progress count, publishing a ProgressEvent if necessary.
        Parameters:
        count - the new progress count
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this ProgressMonitor has completed
        IllegalArgumentException - if count < progress or count > maximum

      • getProgress

        public long getProgress()
        Returns the progress count.
        Returns:
        the progress count

      • completed

        public void completed()
        Marks this ProgressMonitor as completed, publishing the final ProgressEvent if necessary. Logically this signifies the end of the operation.

        Calling this method multiple times is always permitted and will have no subsequent effect. Any further attempts to modify the state of this ProgressMonitor will result in an IllegalStateException until it is reset.

      • isDone

        public boolean isDone()
        Returns true if this ProgressMonitor has completed.
        Returns:
        true if this ProgressMonitor has completed

      • reset

        public ProgressMonitor reset()
        Resets this ProgressMonitor to its initial state, retaining all previously added ProgressListeners and the maximum value. After this call returns the isDone() method will return false, getProgress() will return 0, and if the step size is dynamic, it will be reset to the minimum value.
        Returns:
        this ProgressMonitor instance
